user.biography: RSN helps young refugees access, remain and progress in education

node.text: With half-term on the horizon, those long days are coming back, but this time it won’t be as sunny outside. Hear from the most wonderful friend of ours, B, on how she manages to stay positive while away from #college. #refugees #positivevibes

node.title: Dear Friend: how to stay positive during lockdown

node.text: Can you help young people in London build hopeful futures through education? This video explains the campaign. Get involved!

node.title: Champions for Children Campaign: The Childhood Trust and RSN

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network in United States Capitol. Image may contain: 1 person, indoor.

node.text:
Word of the building project is spreading!

Thank you so much to everyone who has supported our campaign so far and who are joining us for this project. Still some way to go but the future is bright! 

#berniesanders #growthmindset #journey #refugees #education #building

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 27, 2020. Image may contain: text that says 'Hope 60 Harlesden High Street Street will be a space for young people to develop hope, plan for the future and invest in themselves as they build lives here in the UK'.

node.text:
Why are we posting so much about a disused building?

Hopefully these images explain why we are doing everything we can to make this building perfect for the young refugees who inspire us every day. 

You can help make it happen. If you want to support the project or learn more about it, click the link in our bio!

#hope #diversity #collaboration #privacy #education #refugees

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 27, 2020. Image may contain: text that says 'Hope 60 Harlesden High Street Street will be a space for young people to develop hope, plan for the future and invest in themselves as they build lives here in the UK'.

Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 27, 2020. Image may contain: text that says 'Privacy The building will create confidential meeting rooms for young people to discuss their experience and situation, to be heard and to be supported in the way that they need'.

Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 27, 2020. Image may contain: text that says 'Collaboration We do more when we act together. This building will enable young people, organisations, initiatives and social impact projects to work together, untangle problems and build positive futures'.

Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 27, 2020. Image may contain: text that says 'Diversity This building will be a space for people from all over the world to come together, to grow, to learn and to celebrate our similarities and differences'.

node.text:
We have contractors in the building! Jovany and the team are doing what we call a ‘soft strip-out’, which means taking the building down to its basics, taking out the partition walls we won’t need anymore and removing the cladding on the main walls so we can see what condition they are in. 

They’re also exposing the roof so we can see how bad the damp is (fingers crossed). It’s amazing seeing the progress and how big the space is once the unnecessary walls are down (many of which had steel plates in them - it really was a bank!). 

So far 3 lovely people from our Instagram account have decided to support the project to turn this place into an education centre for young refugees and a head office for RSN and our partners. You know who you are - thank you!! If you want to support the project, donations are doubled until the end of the year! Link as ever is in our bio. 

Happy #christmas all!

node.text: The amazing Diwa explains why young refugees need somewhere to meet others in similar situations. As ever the link to support the project is in our bio. #hero #leadingtheway

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 18, 2020. Image may contain: sky and nature, text that says '"We need to find ways of making people aware of how lucky we are to have people coming here with skills, resilience and determination We need to be grateful for immigration. T'.

node.text:
This #internationalmigrantsday we thought we’d share this reflection from a fellow at the Forward Institute when she met young refugees over Zoom last week. We couldn’t agree more. 

Keep your 👀for a blog about the event next week. If you like our content and what we’re doing at RSN please forward the link to our fundraising page (link in bio)! Thanks!

#weekend

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 18, 2020. Image may contain: indoor.

node.text:
Day 2! 🏫 🔨👷‍♀️

We’re sharing pics of the building project that hundreds of you have supported so far. There’s still a long way to go, physically, financially and emotionally but right now we’re excited!!

We’ve been thinking carefully about how we can get the most out of the building when it’s time to love in. Got any good ideas for this space, which will be kept open for events and classes?

Let us know! We’re looking to support local initiatives in #harlseden and #brent and #london at the very least!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 18, 2020. Image may contain: indoor.
Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 18, 2020.
Photo by Refugee Support Network in Harlesden High Street. Image may contain: 3 people, people standing, beard and outdoor.

node.text:
BUILDING UPDATE: 

Over a year on from when the dream began, John and Jovany today took the first physical steps in transforming the building. For the next week or so, their team will be stripping out everything in the bank so we can begin from scratch when the main works begin. This includes old bank equipment, vault doors, dials and the crumbling wallpaper. Cheers guys!

Today has felt like the first physical step in setting the foundation for an amazing space for young refugees, for literally decades to come. Excuse us if we're a bit emotional about it!

If you want to support the project, please click the link in our bio and consider making a donation. What we can create in the space available is still to be determined - the more you give now the more we can create for young refugees, the more welcoming the environment will be for them and the louder we can say to them together, 'you are infinitely valuable'. 

Remember, your donations until January 1st doubled! 

#building #transform #create #emotional #grateful #excited #progress #RefugeeEducation #refugeeswelcome

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 16, 2020.

node.text:
Instagram is for images, not text! That’s unless you’re really proud of your inclusion in City of Sanctuary’s great resource on what #FE colleges can do to support refugees and asylum-seekers. 

Have a read! The city of #sanctuary movement is a great one and we hope that as many colleges commit to becoming #CollegesofSanctuary ASAP!

#Normalise refugee education! 🏫🧑‍🏫👩‍🏫👨‍🏫

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network in Oxford, Oxfordshire, UK. Image may contain: 1 person, text that says 'B (17) speaks minimal English. We are now doing our support work through an Arabic interpreter as it was difficult to understand each other without. It's transpired that he was actually excluded from school last year, which he'd not wanted or been able to communicate previously. We are working on a re-enrolment plan for him and will be using a donated laptop in our sessions once we start face-to- face ESOL together next term.'.

node.text:
It’s not always easy. 

Progress in education for young refugees is gradual and can be slow at times. Ever since RSN started we have been careful to go at each young person’s pace, to make it work for them in their unique situation and with their own experience in mind. Making assumptions and generalisations about ‘the refugee experience’ doesn’t get anyone anywhere.

Guys like B are doing their best during #covid_19. To help them over the hurdles this Christmas, please consider supporting our campaign for an education centre for young refugees. Link as ever is in the bio. 

Have a lovely #weekend!

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network in Harlesden High Street. Image may contain: 1 person, text.

node.text:
🏗Now is the time to transform the old bank in #Harlesden into an education centre for young refugees! 🚨

This Christmas we are making a small ask for a big project - turning the bank into a head office and an education space for hundreds of young refugees for literally decades to come. 

We are almost there but need your help to get it over the line. Click the link in our bio for more details and to make a donation 🙏

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Refugee Support Network on December 06, 2020.

node.text:
'Education is very important because it gives me the #knowledge of the world and changes it into something better' 

So heartwarming and motivating to receive messages like this from young refugees. #Education support can make a massive difference for young people's self-worth and self-belief, particularly when they have just arrived and are learning English, and especially when they are on their own.
